# State Eligibility Matrix

Quick reference for expungement eligibility across all 50 states + DC.

## Legend

**Eligibility Rating:**
- A = Excellent (most offenses, short waits)
- B = Good (many offenses, moderate waits)
- C = Fair (limited offenses, longer waits)
- D = Poor (few offenses, very long waits)
- F = Very Limited (almost nothing qualifies)

**Clean Slate:**
- Y = Has automatic expungement
- P = Pending/partial automatic
- N = No automatic expungement

---

## At-a-Glance Table

| State | Rating | Clean Slate | Misdemeanor Wait | Felony Wait | Key Notes |
|-------|--------|-------------|------------------|-------------|-----------|
| AL | D | N | 5 years | Ineligible most | Very limited |
| AK | C | N | 3 years | Limited | Few qualify |
| AZ | C | N | Completion | Completion | Set-aside, not expungement |
| AR | C | N | 5 years | 5 years | Limited offenses |
| CA | A | Y | 1-2 years | 1-2 years | PC 1203.4 dismissal |
| CO | B | Y | 3 years | 3-7 years | Sealing available |
| CT | A | Y | 7 years | 10 years | Strong Clean Slate |
| DE | B | Y | 3-7 years | 5-10 years | Clean Slate 2021 |
| DC | B | N | 2-8 years | 8 years | Motion to seal |
| FL | C | N | 5 years | Ineligible most | Sealing vs expungement |
| GA | C | N | 2-5 years | Limited | Restriction, not expungement |
| HI | C | N | Varies | Varies | Deferred only |
| ID | C | N | 5 years | 5 years | Limited |
| IL | A | Y | 2-3 years | 3-5 years | Strong Clean Slate |
| IN | C | N | 5 years | 8-10 years | Limited felonies |
| IA | C | N | 8 years | Ineligible | Very limited |
| KS | C | N | 3-5 years | Ineligible most | Limited |
| KY | B | N | 5 years | 5 years | Expanded 2016 |
| LA | B | N | 5 years | 10 years | Waiting from conviction |
| ME | C | N | 4 years | 4 years | Limited |
| MD | B | Y | 3-10 years | 10-15 years | Clean Slate 2024 |
| MA | B | P | 3 years | 7 years | Sealing available |
| MI | A | Y | 7 years | 7-10 years | Strong Clean Slate |
| MN | A | Y | 2-5 years | 5-7 years | Clean Slate 2023 |
| MS | C | N | 5 years | Ineligible most | Very limited |
| MO | B | N | 3-7 years | 7 years | Expanded 2016/2018 |
| MT | C | N | Varies | Ineligible most | Limited |
| NE | C | N | 10 years | Limited | Very long waits |
| NV | B | N | 1-7 years | 5-15 years | Certificate available |
| NH | C | N | Completion | 10 years | Limited |
| NJ | A | Y | Immediate-5 yr | 6-10 years | Strong Clean Slate |
| NM | B | N | 2-10 years | 10 years | Expanded |
| NY | A | Y | 3 years | 10 years | Clean Slate 2023 |
| NC | B | N | 5 years | 10-15 years | First offense focus |
| ND | C | N | 3-5 years | Ineligible most | Limited |
| OH | B | N | 1-3 years | 3-10 years | Sealing available |
| OK | B | Y | 5 years | 5-15 years | Clean Slate 2022 |
| OR | A | Y | 3 years | 7-20 years | Strong set-aside |
| PA | A | Y | Varies | Varies | First Clean Slate |
| RI | C | N | 5 years | 10 years | First offense focus |
| SC | D | N | 3 years | Ineligible | Very limited |
| SD | D | N | Varies | Ineligible most | Very limited |
| TN | D | N | N/A | N/A | Diversion only |
| TX | C | N | N/A (arrests) | N/A | Nondisclosure only |
| UT | B | Y | Varies | 5-10 years | Clean Slate arrests |
| VT | B | N | 5 years | 10-20 years | Moderate |
| VA | B | Y | Varies | Limited | Clean Slate 2021 |
| WA | B | N | 3-5 years | 5-10 years | Vacate available |
| WV | C | N | 1-2 years | Ineligible most | Limited |
| WI | F | N | At sentencing | At sentencing | Must request at sentencing |
| WY | D | N | Limited | Ineligible | Very limited |

---

## Detailed State Profiles

### A-Rated States (Excellent)

#### California (CA)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (AB 1076, 2020)
Terminology: Dismissal (PC 1203.4)
Misdemeanor wait: 1-2 years from completion
Felony wait: 1-2 years from completion (non-violent)
Key exclusions: Sex offenses, violent felonies
Special: Marijuana automatic (AB 1793)
```

#### Connecticut (CT)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (PA 21-32, 2021)
Terminology: Erasure
Misdemeanor wait: 7 years (automatic)
Felony wait: 10 years Class D/E (automatic)
Key exclusions: Class A-C felonies, sex offenses
Special: One of strongest Clean Slate laws
```

#### Illinois (IL)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (SB 2122, 2024)
Terminology: Expungement/Sealing
Misdemeanor wait: 2-3 years
Felony wait: 3-5 years (sealing, not expungement)
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, sex offenses, DUI
Special: Extensive automatic provisions
```

#### Michigan (MI)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2020)
Terminology: Set aside
Misdemeanor wait: 7 years (automatic)
Felony wait: 7-10 years
Key exclusions: Assaultive crimes, crimes > 10 years
Special: First state with felony Clean Slate
```

#### Minnesota (MN)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2023)
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 2-5 years
Felony wait: 5-7 years
Key exclusions: Murder, sex offenses
Special: Automatic after waiting period
```

#### New Jersey (NJ)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2019)
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 5 years (can be immediate if only one)
Felony wait: 6-10 years
Key exclusions: Murder, robbery, sex offenses
Special: "Clean Slate" law model for others
```

#### New York (NY)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2023)
Terminology: Sealing
Misdemeanor wait: 3 years (automatic)
Felony wait: 10 years Class D/E (automatic)
Key exclusions: Sex offenses, Class A-C felonies
Special: Effective 2027 for felonies
```

#### Oregon (OR)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2025)
Terminology: Set-aside
Misdemeanor wait: 3 years from completion
Felony wait: 7 years (Class C), 10 years (person felonies)
Key exclusions: Class A felonies, sex offenses, DUI
Special: Marijuana only 1 year
```

#### Pennsylvania (PA)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2018 - first in US)
Terminology: Expungement/Sealing
Misdemeanor wait: 10 years arrest-free (automatic)
Felony wait: Petition only, varies
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, multiple convictions
Special: First Clean Slate state
```

---

### B-Rated States (Good)

#### Colorado (CO)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2022)
Terminology: Sealing
Misdemeanor wait: 3 years
Felony wait: 3-7 years (sealing)
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, DUI
```

#### Delaware (DE)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2021)
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 3-7 years
Felony wait: 5-10 years
Key exclusions: Violent felonies
```

#### Kentucky (KY)
```
Clean Slate: No
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 5 years
Felony wait: 5 years (Class D only)
Key exclusions: Sex offenses, violent crimes
Note: Dramatically expanded in 2016
```

#### Louisiana (LA)
```
Clean Slate: No
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 5 years
Felony wait: 10 years
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, sex offenses
```

#### Maryland (MD)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2024)
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 3-10 years
Felony wait: 10-15 years
Key exclusions: Violent crimes
```

#### Missouri (MO)
```
Clean Slate: No
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 3-7 years
Felony wait: 7 years
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, DUI, sex offenses
Note: Expanded significantly 2016/2018
```

#### North Carolina (NC)
```
Clean Slate: No
Terminology: Expunction
Misdemeanor wait: 5 years
Felony wait: 10-15 years
Key exclusions: Most felonies limited
Note: Focus on first offenders
```

#### Ohio (OH)
```
Clean Slate: No (considering)
Terminology: Sealing/Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 1-3 years
Felony wait: 3-10 years
Key exclusions: Violent offenses, first/second degree felonies
```

#### Oklahoma (OK)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2022)
Terminology: Expungement
Misdemeanor wait: 5 years (automatic nonviolent)
Felony wait: 5-15 years
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, sex offenses
```

#### Virginia (VA)
```
Clean Slate: Yes (2021)
Terminology: Sealing
Misdemeanor wait: Varies by offense
Felony wait: Limited eligibility
Key exclusions: DUI, violent crimes
Note: Implementation ongoing
```

#### Washington (WA)
```
Clean Slate: No (considering)
Terminology: Vacating
Misdemeanor wait: 3-5 years
Felony wait: 5-10 years
Key exclusions: Violent crimes, sex offenses
```

---

### C-Rated States (Fair)

Brief profiles for states with moderate eligibility:

**Alaska (AK)**: Limited to specific offenses, 3-year wait for misdemeanors
**Arizona (AZ)**: Set-aside available upon completion (not true expungement)
**Arkansas (AR)**: 5-year wait, limited felony eligibility
**Florida (FL)**: Sealing common, expungement rare; 5-year wait
**Georgia (GA)**: Restriction orders, limited true expungement
**Hawaii (HI)**: Deferred acceptance only
**Idaho (ID)**: Limited eligibility, 5-year waits
**Indiana (IN)**: 5-8 year waits, limited felonies
**Iowa (IA)**: 8 years minimum, very limited
**Kansas (KS)**: Limited felony eligibility
**Maine (ME)**: 4-year wait, limited offenses
**Massachusetts (MA)**: Sealing available, considering Clean Slate
**Montana (MT)**: Very limited felony eligibility
**Nebraska (NE)**: 10-year waits, very limited
**Nevada (NV)**: Sealing available, certificates of rehabilitation
**New Hampshire (NH)**: 10-year felony wait
**New Mexico (NM)**: 2-10 year waits depending on offense
**North Dakota (ND)**: Limited eligibility
**Rhode Island (RI)**: First offense focus
**Texas (TX)**: Only arrests expungable; convictions only nondisclosure
**Utah (UT)**: Clean Slate for arrests only; petition for convictions
**Vermont (VT)**: 5-20 year waits
**West Virginia (WV)**: Limited felony eligibility

---

### D & F-Rated States (Poor/Very Limited)

**Alabama (AL)**: Very limited—primarily arrests and traffic only
**Mississippi (MS)**: Very limited—first offense focus, few felonies
**South Carolina (SC)**: Very limited—first offense only
**South Dakota (SD)**: Very limited—primarily youthful offenders
**Tennessee (TN)**: NO true expungement—diversion at time of plea only
**Wisconsin (WI)**: MUST be requested at sentencing—cannot petition later
**Wyoming (WY)**: Very limited—primarily DNA records

---

## Clean Slate Implementation Timeline

| Year | State | Key Provisions |
|------|-------|----------------|
| 2018 | PA | First Clean Slate - arrests + summary offenses |
| 2019 | UT | Arrests only automatic |
| 2019 | NJ | Most convictions after 10 years |
| 2020 | MI | Arrests 7yr, misdemeanors 7-10yr, some felonies |
| 2020 | CA | Arrests + conviction relief expansion |
| 2021 | CT | Misdemeanors 7yr, Class D/E felonies 10yr |
| 2021 | DE | Misdemeanors 7yr automatic |
| 2021 | VA | Limited automatic provisions |
| 2022 | OK | Nonviolent offenses after waiting period |
| 2022 | CO | Expanded sealing automatic |
| 2023 | NY | Most misdemeanors 3yr, Class D/E felonies 10yr |
| 2023 | MN | Broad automatic after waiting periods |
| 2024 | MD | Expanded categories |
| 2024 | IL | Extensive automatic provisions |
| 2025 | OR | Broad automatic sealing |

---

## Special Categories

### Marijuana-Specific Relief

States with enhanced marijuana expungement:
- **California**: Automatic review (AB 1793)
- **Illinois**: Automatic < 30g possession
- **Colorado**: Cannabis conviction sealing
- **New Jersey**: Included in Clean Slate
- **Oregon**: 1-year wait (vs 3 for other misdemeanors)
- **New York**: Automatic for marijuana convictions
- **Vermont**: Automatic for possession < 1 oz

### Juvenile Records

Most states seal juvenile records automatically:
- **California**: Sealed at 18, destroyed at 21
- **New York**: Auto-sealed at 21
- **Texas**: Sealed at 21 for most
- **Illinois**: Sealed upon reaching 17+
- **Michigan**: Sealed at 18 for most

Exceptions requiring petition:
- Sex offenses involving minors
- Violent felonies tried as adult
- Cases transferred to adult court

### Diversion/Deferred Adjudication

States where diversion = easy expungement:
- **Oregon**: Dismissed upon completion
- **California**: Diversion completion = dismissal
- **New York**: ACD (Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal)

States where deferred = still conviction:
- **Texas**: Deferred adjudication still appears
- **Georgia**: First offender still conviction for some purposes

# National Expungement Expert

Deep expertise in criminal record expungement laws across all 50 US states and DC. Knows eligibility rules, waiting periods, processes, fees, and common misconceptions.

## When to Use This Skill

Use this skill when you need to:

- **Determine eligibility** for expungement in any state
- **Explain waiting periods** and how they're calculated
- **Describe the expungement process** step by step
- **Clarify misconceptions** about what expungement does and doesn't do
- **Compare state laws** for users who've lived in multiple states
- **Advise on special categories**: marijuana, juvenile, Clean Slate automatic
- **Draft content** for the National Expungement Guide website

**Do NOT use this skill for:**
- Finding URLs or scraping data (use `2026-legal-research-agent`)
- Providing actual legal advice to real users (always disclaim)
- Building UI components or code

## Core Knowledge

### Fundamental Expungement Concepts

**What expungement actually does** (varies by state):

- **Full Expungement**: Record destroyed or permanently sealed, can legally say "no" to conviction questions
- **Sealing**: Record exists but hidden from public view, law enforcement can still see
- **Limited Expungement**: Specific offenses only removed

### State Classification System

**Clean Slate States** (automatic expungement):
Pennsylvania, Utah, New Jersey, Michigan, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Virginia, Colorado, Oklahoma, New York, Minnesota, Maryland, Illinois, Oregon

**Progressive States** (broad eligibility):
Oregon, California, Michigan, New Jersey, Minnesota

**Restrictive States** (limited eligibility):
Alabama, Arizona, South Carolina, Wyoming

### Common Misconceptions

- "Expungement erases everything" - FBI records may persist
- "After X years, it automatically comes off" - Only in Clean Slate states
- "Federal convictions can be expunged" - Only presidential pardon works
- "Expungement in one state applies everywhere" - Only affects that state's records

## Anti-Patterns

1. **Never provide actual legal advice** - Always disclaim
2. **Never guarantee outcomes** - Even clear cases can be denied
3. **Never assume federal follows state** - Federal records are separate
4. **Never oversimplify waiting periods** - They're complex
